subject: Re: [junit] utility class vs. base class
msgSnippet: Extract the common code to a base test fixture. If a second suite of tests later require the same code, consider a utility class at that stage - with its own
messageBody:
Extract the common code to a base test fixture. If a second suite of
tests later require the same code, consider a utility class at that
stage - with its own tests, of course. ;)

---
Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/

Scott Glaser wrote:
>
>
> I have a question about designing JUnit tests. I have some common setup and
> teardown tasks that are shared amongst several test classes. For example I
> read test data from an xml file used by each test class that contains global
> information like Locale and Timezone. Another is removing test data from the
> db. These are not tasks I want to do once per test class but once per test
> method in several test classes. I would think it makes more sense to pull
> out these common tasks from each test class and either put them in a
> utility/helper class or create a base test class that each test class will
> inherit. The dilemma I have is which approach is better. Creating a utility
> class or creating a base test class that is inherited. The common tasks are
> not package specific, meaning they are not targeting a specific suite of
> test classes so my initial thought is to create a utility class for these
> common tasks to reside. This may seem to be more of a general java design
> question but was hoping someone can give me some pointers.
>
> Thanks,
> Scott
